experimental_info.description: Experimental XRD and TGA data for Portland cement + 30% fly ash paste at 28 days

measurement_methods.XRD: Rietveld refinement with external standard method
measurement_methods.laboratory: Tongji University Advanced Civil Engineering Materials Lab

notes: TGA mass loss attributed to specific decomposition ranges
Trace phases (<0.5 wt%) excluded per client instruction
Data represents average of 3 replicate measurements

xrd_quantification.description: Rietveld refinement results for crystalline phases (wt% of paste)

portlandite.notes: Main pH buffer, dissolution controls Stage 2 degradation

ettringite.notes: AFt phase, susceptible to sulfate attack and decalcification

monosulfate.notes: AFm phase, converts to Friedel's salt upon chloride exposure

hydrotalcite.notes: Mg-Al layered double hydroxide from MgO in cement

C3S_unreacted.notes: Unreacted alite, ~7.3% of original C3S remains at 28d

C2S_unreacted.notes: Unreacted belite, ~14% of original C2S remains at 28d

C4AF_unreacted.notes: Unreacted ferrite, ~55% of original C4AF remains at 28d

calcite.notes: From original cement filler, no carbonation under sealed curing

quartz_FA.notes: Unreacted quartz from fly ash (12% of FA)

mullite_FA.notes: Unreacted mullite from fly ash (15% of FA)

xrd_quantification.notes: Total crystalline = 45.5%, amorphous = 54.5% (C-S-H gel + FA glass + water)

tga_analysis.description: Thermogravimetric analysis mass loss in specific temperature ranges

free_water.notes: Not chemically bound, varies with drying conditions

CSH_gel_water.attribution: C-S-H gel interlayer water + AFt/AFm hydrate water
CSH_gel_water.notes: Main mass loss peak, overlapping decomposition reactions

comparison_with_XRD.discrepancy_reason: TGA includes nanocrystalline CH not detected by XRD

portlandite.notes: TGA typically overestimates due to C-S-H dehydroxylation overlap

carbonate_decomposition.notes: Minor carbonation from ambient CO2 during sample handling

derived_phase_assemblage.description: Phase assemblage derived from combined XRD+TGA analysis (wt% of paste)
derived_phase_assemblage.method: Cross-validation of XRD Rietveld with TGA mass loss attribution

CSH_gel.notes: Amorphous in XRD, quantified from TGA water loss and mass balance
CSH_gel.calculation_basis: Total mass - crystalline phases - FA glass - evaporable water

portlandite.notes: XRD more reliable due to TGA overlap with C-S-H dehydroxylation

FA_glass_unreacted.notes: 73% glass in FA, ~80% reacted at 28d, 20% remains = 0.20 × 73% × 16g FA = 11.7%

unhydrated_clinker.notes: C3A fully reacted by 28d, only residual C3S, C2S, C4AF

mullite.notes: Inert phase from fly ash, no reaction

quartz.notes: Inert phase from fly ash, no reaction

pore_solution_chemistry.description: Pore solution composition at 28 days (sealed curing, no degradation)
pore_solution_chemistry.measurement_method: Pore expression at 500 MPa followed by ICP-OES and IC
notes: High alkali (Na+K) concentration typical of fly ash blends
Low Ca due to C-S-H uptake and lower portlandite solubility at high pH
pH controlled by alkali hydroxides with portlandite saturation

porosity.notes: Low w/b and fly ash refinement produce dense microstructure

degree_of_hydration.notes: Cement ~78% hydrated, FA pozzolanic reaction ~20% at 28d (will continue to 90d+)

density_g_cm3.notes: Calculated from porosity and solid phase densities

calibration_targets.description: Key phase assemblage targets for model calibration

portlandite.importance: Critical for pH buffering and Stage 2 degradation
portlandite.calibration_note: Adjust cement hydration degree if needed

CSH_gel.importance: Main binding phase, controls mechanical properties
CSH_gel.calibration_note: Adjust C-S-H model parameters (CSHQ α, β)

ettringite.importance: Sulfate reservoir, affected by sulfate attack
ettringite.calibration_note: Check SO3 balance and C3A hydration

monosulfate.importance: Chloride binding capacity via Friedel's salt formation
monosulfate.calibration_note: AFm/AFt equilibrium sensitive to SO4/Al ratio

unhydrated_clinker.importance: Validates hydration kinetics and final strength
unhydrated_clinker.calibration_note: Adjust DOH if total clinker deviates

FA_glass.calibration_note: 20% reaction at 28d is reasonable for low-Ca FA

porosity.notes: Check volume balance and water consumption

alkali_concentration.notes: Na+K in pore solution, affects leaching Stage 1

validation_notes.data_quality: High - experimental measurements from reputable laboratory
validation_notes.representativeness: Excellent - same mix design as modeled paste
validation_notes.measurement_uncertainty: Quantified for all major phases (±0.3-0.8 wt%)
limitations: XRD cannot detect poorly crystalline or amorphous phases directly
TGA decomposition ranges overlap, requiring deconvolution
Pore solution extraction may alter chemistry (carbonation risk)
MIP may damage microstructure, underestimating finest pores
validation_notes.confidence_level: Suitable for model calibration and validation
recommended_calibration_workflow: 1. Compare model baseline_28d.json with experimental phases
2. Calculate absolute and relative errors for each phase
3. If |error| > tolerance: adjust hydration degrees or thermodynamic data
4. Prioritize portlandite, C-S-H, ettringite (key degradation phases)
5. Validate pore solution chemistry (pH, alkalis, Ca)
6. Check mass and volume balance closure
8. Re-run Phase 4 simulations if baseline updated

literature_comparison.description: Comparison with published data for similar paste compositions

references.citation: Lothenbach et al. (2011) Cement and Concrete Research 41, 238-249
references.notes: Higher w/b → more portlandite; our 12.3% reasonable for w/b=0.3

references.citation: Scrivener et al. (2015) Cement and Concrete Research 78, 110-126
references.notes: 30% FA dilution reduces portlandite; our value consistent

references.citation: Snellings et al. (2012) Cement and Concrete Research 42, 903-913
references.notes: Our 20% reaction higher due to lower w/b (denser packing → more contact)

literature_comparison.conclusion: Experimental data consistent with published literature for comparable systems
